t: Isaiah 32
The Glorious Future
Behold,*pn a king will reign righteously And*ln princes will rule justly.
Each*ln will be like a refuge from the wind And*ln a shelter from the storm, Like*ln streams of water in a dry country, Like*ln the shade of a huge rock in a parched land.
Then*ln the eyes of those who see will not be blinded, And*ln the ears of those who hear will listen.
The*ln mind of the hasty will discern the truth, And*ln the tongue of the stammerers will hasten to speak clearly.
No*ln longer will the fool be called noble, Or*ln the rogue be spoken of as*i generous.

For*ln a fool speaks nonsense, And*ln his heart inclines toward wickedness: To*ln practice ungodliness and to speak error against the Lord,*s To*ln keep the hungry person unsatisfied And*ln to withhold drink from the thirsty.
As*ln for a rogue, his weapons are evil; He*ln devises wicked schemes To*ln destroy the*i afflicted with slander, Even*ln though the*i needy one speaks what is right.
But*ln the noble man devises noble plans; And*ln by noble plans he stands.
Rise*ln up, you women who are at ease, And*iln hear my voice; Give*ln ear to my word, You*ln complacent daughters.
Within*ln a year and a*i few*i days You*ln will be troubled, O complacent daughters;*i For*ln the vintage is ended, And*iln the fruit*i gathering will not come.
Tremble,*ln you women*i who are at ease; Be*ln troubled, you complacent daughters;*i Strip,*ln undress and put sackcloth*i on your*i waist,
Beat*ln your breasts for the pleasant fields, for the fruitful vine,
For*ln the land of my people in*i which*i thorns and*i briars shall come up; Yea,*ln for all the joyful houses and*i for*i the jubilant city.
Because*ln the palace has been abandoned, the populated city forsaken. Hill*ln and watch-tower have become caves forever, A*ln delight for wild donkeys, a pasture for flocks;
Until*ln the Spirit is poured out upon us from on high, And*ln the wilderness becomes a fertile field, And*ln the fertile field is considered as a forest.
Then*ln justice will dwell in the wilderness And*ln righteousness will abide in the fertile field.
And*ln the work of righteousness will be peace, And*ln the service of righteousness, quietness and confidence forever.
Then*ln my people will live in a peaceful habitation, And*ln in secure dwellings and in undisturbed resting places;
And*ln it will hail when the forest comes down, And*ln the city will be utterly laid low.
How*ln blessed will you be, you who sow beside all waters, Who*ln let out freely the ox and the donkey.
